data.title: 24 Good Princess in Black Read Alike Books
data.meta_description: If you love the Princess in Black books, here are good read alike books to read next; fantasy and adventure books with strong female heroines.
data.text:
The Princess in Black chapter book series by Shannon Hale and illustrated by LeUyen Pham is a popular fictional adventure about a spunky princess who secretly fights monsters. It’s a hugely popular beginning chapter book. If your kids love The Princess in Black books, here are more fantasy and adventure read alike book ideas to read next; books that they’ll love just as much.

How many Princess in Black books are there?

At this time, there are ten books in the series. Find all the Princess in Black books on Amazon or Bookshop.

What are the series titles in order?

Book 1: The Princess in Black

Book 2: The Princess in Black and the Perfect Princess Party

Book 3: The Princess in Black and the Hungry Bunny Horde

Book 4: The Princess in Black Takes a Vacation

Book 5: The Princess in Black and the Mysterious Playdate

Book 6: The Princess in Black and the Science Fair Scare

Book 7: The Princess in Black and the Bathtime Battle

Book 8: The Princess in Black and the Giant Problem

Book 9: The Princess in Black and the Mermaid Princess

Book 10: The Princess in Black and the Princess in Pink

What ages and grade levels should read Princess in Black?

The tricky thing for me when recommending read-alike books is to give you titles that are more or less at the same reading comprehension level.

First let’s start with the Princess in Black titles. Their reading level is around 1st – 2nd grade with a

guided reading level of L and M, a Lexile level between 340 – 500, and a DRA level between 20 – 24.

The books list first on this list are around the same reading level which, depending on the books, also contain plots with strong female main characters and are either fantasy or realistic for first or second grades.

Of course, they’re all great stories that keep kids reading.

Read Alike Books for Kids Who Love Princess in Black

Meet Yasmin! by Saadia Faruqui, illustrated by Hatem Aly

Yasmin is an exuberant girl interested in everything from exploring to building to fashion. This book tells four short stories from Yasmin’s life, all in chapters with lively, full-color illustrations. Each story shows Yasmin as a creative problem solver even when things get hard. Her Pakistani American culture is embedded throughout the story such as the foods Yasmin’s family eats like naan or how she calls her father Baba.

Owl Diaries Eva’s Treetop Festival by Rebecca Elliott

This series pops with cute diary entries with colorful illustrations; it’s just right for beginning readers, particularly girls. In this book, Eva writes in her diary about getting the Bloomtastic Festival organized and how she eventually learns to ask friends for help.

Olive & Beatrix The Super Smelly Moldy Blob by Amy Marie Stadelmann

It’s science fair time and these twins, one who is a witch and one who is a super smart science nerd, are in it to win it. Except disaster happens when the girls fight and their projects combine to form a huge green blog that absorbs everything. It will take both their skills to fix this slimy problem. An enjoyable book series for 5- and 6- year old readers.

Bink & Gollie Best Friends Forever by Kate DiCamillo and Alison McGhee, illustrated by Tony Fucile

The second book of funny Bink and Gollie (mis)adventures in friendship and life filled wonderful color illustrations. Get the first book here. Kids, girls especially, love these stories!

The Fabled Stables Willa the Wisp by Jonathan Auxier, illustrated by Olga Demidova

Auggie, the only human, lives on an island of mythical creatures but he’s lonely. When a new stall magically appears, Auggie enters and meets a Wisp who is hunted by ruthless magical poachers. It’s a darling start to a new series perfect for fantasy-loving readers.

Jessica Finch in Pig Trouble by Megan McDonald, illustrated by Erwin Madrid

Jessica Finch is a delightful beginning chapter book with exceptionally pleasing and colorful illustrations. Jessica wants nothing more than a pig for a pet. For her birthday. When a misunderstanding happens with her best friend, Judy Moody, she learns a valuable lesson about not making assumptions and calling people names.

A Bit Harder Easy Chapter Books for Kids Who Love The Princess in Black

These books are just a little bit harder than Princess in Black but will be just as well-loved. These are guided reading levels M and up and Lexile levels 500 to 800.

Diary of an Ice Princess: Snow Place Like Home by Christina Soontornvat

This charming new series for early readers features magic, friendship, myths, and diversity in a story about a girl whose family are windtamers who live in the clouds, magical beings who control the wind and weather. Unfortunately, Princess Lina’s powers are going wonky, especially when she gets upset. Luckily, her wise (and loud) grandfather helps Lina discover her true talents.

Mia Mayhem Is a Superhero! by Kara West, illustrated by Leeza Hernandez

When Mia gets accepted into the Superhero training program, she learns that she is SUPER. She even learns that her parents are, also. After school at her new superhero training, she has a disastrous first day and learns that it takes work to become a superhero. Black and white illustrations, bigger print, and an exciting story make this a winning series for growing readers.

Zoey and Sassafras Dragons and Marshmallows #1 by Asia Citro, illustrated by Marion Lindsay

This is an entertaining and well-written story with the coolest mix of science and magic, a diverse main character, and fantastic illustrations that will get kids reading and learning. Zoey, like her mom, can see magical creatures and is tasked to care for any injured creatures that might need help. In this story, she uses her science skills (including research and the scientific method) to figure out how to care for a sick baby dragon.

KEEP READING
